title-group.article-title: Energy harvesting using an array of multifunctional resonators

contrib-group.aff: School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, USA

abstract.p: Energy harvesting from structural vibrations using an array of multifunctional resonators based on the theory of locally resonant materials is demonstrated. Such locally resonant structures exhibit a stop band for elastic wave propagation. The band gap frequency range depends on the local resonance frequency of the microstructure. One method to realize this is through the use of an array of embedded resonators where the external work done is stored as kinetic energy of the internal mass when the forcing frequency is close to the local resonance frequency. This mechanism can be used to harvest energy by converting the kinetic energy into electrical energy, thus bestowing a multifunctional utility to the structure. We use a spring-loaded magnet enclosed in a capped poly(methyl methacrylate) tube equipped with copper coils to create a unit cell that acts both as a resonator and as a linear generator. Experiments on a serial array of seven unit cells exhibit a band gap between 146.5 (local resonance frequency) and 171 Hz with a peak voltage generation of 3.03 V at steady state. The continuous effective power generated by a single unit cell across a 1-Ω load resistor is 36 mW, indicating the feasibility of constructing vibration isolation structures that can power simple electronic and microelectromechanical systems devices. The applicability of using the device as a transducer to measure the local resonance frequency and the global resonance frequency of the structure is also discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Energy harvesting techniques for kinetic energy sources have achieved prominence in contemporary research owing to their many advantages. Unlike other alternative energy sources, kinetic energy sources are perennial and easily renewable. The challenge, however, is to develop technologies that ensure that the harvested energy can act as a consistent and sustainable power source for intended applications. Some of the techniques currently being explored and implemented are based on piezoelectricity, electrostatic systems, biomechanical processes, micro wind turbines, and devices that scavenge ambient noise and vibrations (Paradiso and Starner, 2005). A review of the principles and design of motion-driven harvesters for low-power applications was done by Mitcheson et al. (2008). It is also desirable that the device be scalable so as to cater to a wide range of sources and applications. Most vibrational energy harvesters utilizing these techniques are implemented as stand-alone or add-on devices that couple with the kinetic energy source. Thus, the possibility of integrating such technologies with existing structural devices to create a multifunctional clean energy source enhances their overall utility. In the present study, we demonstrate a device that harvests useful vibrational energy while simultaneously filters undesirable structural vibrations using the wave attenuation characteristics of locally resonant structures.

The dynamic characteristics of such locally resonant structures are based on the theory of acoustic metamaterials (AMs) that themselves trace their roots to their electromagnetic counterparts. They exhibit behavior pertaining to elastic wave propagation that is not readily observed in natural materials. Recent research focus has been on AMs that exhibit negative effective mass density and negative bulk modulus. It has been shown that negative effective mass density can be achieved by incorporating locally resonant microstructures in a composite matrix. Such AMs display a stop band that precludes the propagation of elastic waves with frequencies in a specific range called the band gap frequency range. By tailoring the microstructure design, AMs can be used to realize devices that have novel applications like acoustic cloaking (Chen and Chan, 2007; Cummer and Schurig, 2007), superlenses (Zhang et al., 2009), waveguides, filters, and diodes (Liang et al., 2009).

One of the earliest demonstrations of filtering acoustic waves was given by Vincent (1898) using nonlinear oscillators. Milton and Willis (2007) investigated the frequency-dependent behavior of the density of materials with resonating inclusions, showing that the effective mass could be negative. Many researchers have constructed locally resonant AMs and proposed analytical and numerical models to explain their behavior. Locally resonant microstructures can be realized in various ways. Fang et al. (2006) utilize the subwavelength Helmholtz resonators to experimentally demonstrate negative modulus in ultrasonic metamaterials. Negative effective density below a cutoff frequency value was realized using a one-dimensional array of elastic membranes by Lee et al. (2009). Simultaneous negative density and modulus can be obtained using a periodic array of membranes interspaced with side holes as shown by Lee et al. (2010). Liu et al. (2000a, 2000b) and Sheng et al. (2003) created a sonic crystal based on locally resonant microstructures that exhibited spectral gaps within certain tunable frequency ranges that were also described using a simple analytical model (Liu et al., 2005). Hirsekorn (2004) provided numerical simulations verifying these experiments and proposed a heuristic model to estimate the resonance frequencies. Li and Chan (2004) showed the existence of double negative AMs where both effective density and bulk modulus are negative using a microstructure of soft rubber suspended in water. Lazarov and Jensen (2007) studied AMs with nonlinear local oscillators and found that the stop band can be shifted by adjusting the degree of nonlinearity. Huang et al. (2009) presented different analytical models to explain the negative effective mass phenomenon in mass-in-mass lattice systems. They showed that a multidisplacement microstructure continuum model can be used to describe the dispersion and wave attenuation behavior without resort to negative effective mass or density. The existence of more than one stop band for elastic wave propagation for multiresonator mass-in-mass lattice systems was shown by Huang and Sun (2010). Experimental verification of the negative effective mass and low transmission of elastic waves in the band gap frequency range was realized by Yao et al. (2008) via a mass–spring system and was found to have good correlation with the theoretical predictions. The wave attenuation and energy transfer mechanism in the stop band for AMs that consist of locally resonant mass-in-mass units were elucidated by Huang and Sun (2009). It was found that most of the work done by the external force on the system is stored by the internal mass as kinetic energy when the forcing frequency is close to the local resonance frequency (LRF). However, the energy is stored only temporarily by the internal mass and is taken out by the external forcing agency in the form of negative work in a cyclic manner. This mechanism is amenable to integration with an energy harvesting system that can convert the kinetic energy of the internal mass into useful electric energy, thereby enhancing the functionality of the AM.

A linear electromagnetic generator is the simplest and most intuitive scheme that can be coupled to a one-dimensional resonator. Boldea and Nasar (1999) reviewed the various types and applications of linear generators. Linear generators are used in applications where design restrictions prevent the use of the more efficient rotary generators. Energy harvesting linear generators have been successfully implemented in automobile shock absorbers (Gupta et al., 2007), ocean wave buoys (Rhinefrank et al., 2005), microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) devices (Lee et al., 2003; Li et al., 2000), bridge health monitoring (Sazonov et al., 2009), and as stand-alone units in machine tools. Another recent commercial product that demonstrates the feasibility of powering personal electronic devices using human locomotion is the nPower® Personal Energy Generator (PEG, Tremont Electric ). The linear generator used in the PEG is scalable and can be tuned to respond to a range of frequencies. However, there are very few scenarios where the harvesting unit is an intrinsic feature of the vibration isolating structure. Linear generators are broadly classified into two types—moving magnet and stator magnet linear generators. Higher efficiency is achieved when the mass of the moving element is minimized. However, the band gap frequency range in mass-in-mass lattice systems depends on the resonating mass. Hence, a moving magnet linear generator is ideally suited to be used in conjunction with the resonator. The magnet serves as the multifunctional element combining the facets of acoustic filtering and electricity generation.

sec.title: Design and construction
sec.p: An array of unit cells with resonators was constructed based on the resonator lattice model. Each unit cell consists of two principal substructures—the inner resonator unit and the outer casing. They are analogous to the internal mass and the external mass, respectively, in the resonator lattice model. Figure 3 presents a schematic cross-sectional view. An exploded view of a unit cell is shown in Figure 4. A cylindrical neodymium magnet is used as the internal mass that doubles as the permanent magnet for the linear generator. It has a surface field of 0.7179 tesla. Each pole of the magnet is bonded to the ends of a compression spring using a cyanoacrylate adhesive. They have a spring rate of 1.17 kN/m. The two springs and the magnet together form the inner resonator unit. The outer casing is fabricated from a 0.5-in-diameter poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) tube that is cut to a length of 1.5 in. The inner resonator unit is inserted into the tube, and the ends are capped using adhesively bonded PMMA disks. This induces a slight precompression in springs. The conductor coils are installed on the outer casing. There are two coils per unit cell located at an axial separation of 1.9 mm from the north and south poles of the magnet. Each coil is made from 100 turns of enamel-coated copper wire. The coil turns are wound as closely as possible resulting in an average coil thickness and width of about 2 mm. The inner end of the coil nearer to the north pole is connected to the outer end of the other so as to ensure that the current produced in both the coils remains in-phase when the magnet oscillates. Seven such unit cells were constructed and bonded end to end to obtain the test specimen. The material properties, dimensions, and design specifications of the various components are detailed in Tables 1 and 2.

sec.title: Wave propagation test
sec.p: In order to verify the existence of the band gap predicted by the theoretical model, a wave propagation test was performed on the seven unit-cell specimen. A schematic depicting the experimental setup is shown in Figure 5(a). The setup consists of the striker, test specimen, and the transmission bar. The striker is fabricated from a hollow PMMA tube that is capped at both ends. The specimen is bonded to one end of a long hollow capped PMMA tube that acts as the transmission bar. All components have an outer diameter of 0.5 in. The entire setup is suspended from rigid supports using thin, light strings so as to obtain a free-free rod condition. The striker is equipped with hinged rigid swing rods that can be raised to the desired level using a string and pulley arrangement. The setup is aligned in the vertical plane using a spirit level. Two 350-Ω strain gages are used to measure the incident and transmitted stress pulses. The incident stress pulse is measured using a strain gage placed 1 in behind the impact end of the striker. The transmitted pulse is measured by a strain gage located at a distance of 3 in after the specimen–transmission bar interface. The strain gages were connected to Wheatstone bridges, whose output signals were balanced, amplified, and recorded using a digital oscilloscope. A photograph of the experimental setup is shown in Figure 5(b). In this test, the output of the energy harvesting coils was not measured. The striker is raised to about 9 in above the specimen centerline and released to impact the specimen. The strain gage output voltages are converted to stress values.

caption.p: (a) Schematic and (b) experimental setup for wave propagation test.

sec.p: The incident and transmitted stress pulses obtained and their frequency spectrums are shown in Figure 6. The incident pulse has a time duration of 0.003 s and dominant frequency content of 0–350 Hz. The transmitted pulse shows multiple reflections from the unit-cell interfaces and end of the transmission bar. The frequency spectrum of the transmitted pulse before the first reflected wave reaches the transmission bar strain gage shows wave attenuation in the frequency range of 146.5–171 Hz. This agrees well with the theoretically predicted band gap between 140.6 and 176 Hz. The lower bound of the experimentally obtained band gap (146.5 Hz) is higher than the theoretical value (140.6 Hz) because of the variation in the actual LRF of the unit cells in the specimen as observed in the LRF transducer tests discussed in the ensuing sections. The theoretical upper bound of the band gap is a function of the ratio of the internal and external masses of the resonator lattice system (equation (6)). However, the magnitude of attenuation in experiments depends on the attenuation factor (β), which is the imaginary part of the dimensionless wave number (qL) in equation (5). Numerical simulations (Huang and Sun, 2009) reveal that β that is zero below the LRF rapidly increases as ω approaches ω0 and then decays exponentially for values of ω in the band gap, becoming zero again at the theoretical upper bound. Hence, the magnitude of attenuation in the band gap at frequencies close to the upper bound is much smaller than at frequencies close to the lower bound.

caption.p: Time and frequency domain plots of the stress pulses obtained from the (a) striker strain gage and (b) transmission bar strain gage.

sec.title: Voltage and power generation tests
sec.p: The voltage generation test setup is shown in Figure 7(a). The specimen is mounted on an aluminum base attached to the actuator of the shaker. An accelerometer is bonded to the base to measure the input displacement given by the shaker. Each pair of coils on a unit cell is connected in series to the subsequent cell. The output of the seven unit-cell series arrangement is supplied to an alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC) conversion and signal conditioning circuit. The conversion and conditioning circuit consists of a diode bridge made of four Schottky diodes whose output is connected in parallel to a 0.1-µF capacitor that smoothes the DC current. The rectified DC voltage and the output of the accelerometer are measured using a data acquisition card and recorded using a LabVIEW interface. The harmonic excitation is generated using an analog function generator whose output is supplied to a two-stage amplification system. The signal is amplified to ±4 V in the first stage and then to ±400 V by the second stage. The amplified signal drives the actuator onto which the specimen is mounted. The input displacement amplitude was 10 µm.

caption.p: Schematic arrangement of the (a) voltage and (b) power generation tests.

sec.p: During the test, the excitation frequency was varied from about 134 to 155 Hz, and the input voltage from the waveform generator, the accelerometer output, and the rectified generated voltage signal from the unit cells were recorded at intermediate frequency values. Figure 8 shows the time and frequency domain plots of the recorded signals at an excitation frequency of 141.8 Hz. The displacement of the base is obtained by numerically integrating the accelerometer signal twice using a Butterworth filter. Its dominant frequency content is the same as the excitation frequency. The initial portion of the displacement signal shows some fluctuation. It is conjectured that this fluctuation is caused by the transient response of the actuator feedback at startup. The generated voltage also has a time delay until it stabilizes at about 1.35 V. This is due to the transient response of the resonators until the amplitude reaches steady state. After a duration of about 5 s, both the displacement and the generated voltage signals reach steady state. Although the generated AC voltage is converted to DC and conditioned, the signal still retains a low-amplitude driving frequency component as seen in the frequency domain plot in Figure 8(b). A capacitor with a higher rating can be used to reduce this low-amplitude AC component. The variation of the generated voltage with excitation frequency is presented in Figure 9. The peak voltage generated is 3.03 V at an excitation frequency of 144.4 Hz.

sec.p: In the power generation test (Figure 7(b)), a single unit cell was mounted on the shaker, and the voltage drop across a 1-Ω load resistor was measured for various excitation frequencies between 130 and 150 Hz. The root mean square (RMS) voltage over a duration of 5 s after steady state has been reached is computed, and the continuous effective power is obtained using the following relations

The peak continuous effective power generated from a single unit cell is 36 mW at 138 Hz for a load of 1 Ω (Figure 8(b)), which is adequate to power simple electronic and MEMS devices. A 5-mW-rated electronic music box was powered using the harvested energy to verify this ability. The power characteristics of the structural system in an application would depend on the number of units in the array and the load in the circuit. The current design, however, demonstrates the feasibility of realizing a multifunctional efficient energy harvesting system using such a structural system.

sec.title: Local and global resonance frequency transducer tests
sec.p: Although the theoretically computed LRF for the unit cell is 140.6 Hz, in practice, the manufactured unit cells may exhibit slightly different LRFs due to variations in the manufacturing procedure. The number of unit cells used to construct the structure also determines its natural modes. The AM offers the possibility of measuring the actual LRF of each unit cell and the global resonance frequency (GRF) of the structure using the energy harvesting circuit. We use this ability of the AM to act as a transducer to measure the LRF of individual unit cells and the GRF of the seven unit-cell specimen experimentally. Two different techniques are used—shaker test and tap test.

sec.title: Shaker test
sec.p: The experimental setup is similar to the voltage generation test. The specimen is mounted on the base attached to the piezoelectric shaker. Unlike the voltage generation tests, the coils are not connected in series, but each pair of coils from cells 1, 3, and 7 are connected to individual channels of a data acquisition system as shown in Figure 10(a). The output from the other cells is not measured. A sinusoidal excitation is applied to the shaker using the analog waveform generator. The input excitation frequency is varied gradually from 120 to 170 Hz. The peak amplitude of the voltage generated from each cell is plotted against the excitation frequency in Figure 11. Cell 1 generates maximum voltage (0.5 V) at 143 Hz, cell 3 (0.25 V) at 144 Hz, and cell 7 (0.275 V) at 147 Hz. Each cell generates maximum voltage when the excitation frequency is the same as the LRF of the cell. At excitation frequencies below 133 Hz and above 160 Hz, the output voltage from each cell is negligible. Due to the coarse resolution of the waveform generator control knob, it was difficult to obtain more precise control over the excitation frequency. The minimum increment possible was 1 Hz. Hence, the shaker test with the analog waveform generator yields a maximum error of less than 1 Hz in the measured value of the LRF.

sec.title: Tap test
sec.p: In the tap test, the specimen is suspended from a rigid fixture using light strings and leveled using a spirit level so as to ensure a free-free rod condition as shown in Figure 10(b). As in the piezoelectric shaker test, each pair of coils from cells 1, 3, and 7 are connected to the data acquisition system. The accelerometer is attached to the impact end (cell 1) of the specimen. The specimen is impacted with an aluminum rod of 0.5 in diameter. The voltage generated by the three cells and the accelerometer output were recorded for different four trials. Typical amplitude versus frequency plots of the output signals are presented in Figure 12.

caption.p: Time and frequency domain plots obtained from (a) accelerometer, (b) cell 1, (c) cell 3, and (d) cell 7 output signals in a tap test.

sec.p: The tap test results offer insights into the free vibration and electricity generation characteristics of the specimen. The accelerometer output contains two dominant frequency components. The 1-Hz oscillations are due to the rigid body motion of the specimen. The impact force also excites the global natural modes of the specimen. The highest intensity GRF observed was at about 181.5 Hz, as shown in Figure 12(a). The frequency spectrum from the accelerometer does not show any other GRF under 1000 Hz. The frequency domain plots of voltage generated by each of the three cells consist of two major peaks: a high-intensity peak at the GRF and a low-intensity peak at the LRF of the unit cell. The outer casing of the unit cell and the coils attached to it vibrate at the GRF, while the resonator unit oscillates at the LRF. The voltage generated is a function of both these harmonic oscillations. The time domain plots of the generated voltage show a beat frequency of around 35 Hz. Thus, the energy harvest circuit in the tap test serves as a transducer for both the LRF of the resonator and the GRFs of the structure. Table 3 summarizes the results of the four trials and compares them to the results of the shaker test. It is noted that cell 7 has two distinct peaks near the LRF obtained consistently in each of the four trials separated by about 3.5 Hz. A manufacturing defect or debonding of the unit cell–resonator interfaces due to impact damage is assumed to be the cause of this phenomenon. The higher intensity peak among the two is chosen to be the representative of the LRF of cell 7, which is also in agreement with the shaker test result for cell 7. The average LRF values measured for cells 1, 3, and 7 are 144.2, 146.4, and 147.7 Hz, respectively. The average GRF was 181.47 Hz. The slight difference in the measured LRFs from the shaker test and tap test is due to the fact that the maximum voltage values measured in the shaker test may not be exactly at the LRF of the unit cell due to the coarse resolution of the waveform generator. Overall, the tap test is the more accurate method to determine the LRF of the resonators and the GRF of the structure.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Locally resonant structures provide a means to engineer systems that exhibit a band gap frequency range for elastic wave propagation. The resonators store the external work done on the structure in the form of kinetic energy when the forcing frequency is close to the LRF. Such structures can be used for vibration isolation applications. Moreover, this mechanism of wave attenuation imparts the possibility of harvesting the kinetic energy to produce electricity, which confers a multifunctional capability to these structures.

This study serves as a proof of concept for developing systems that provide structural integrity, vibration isolation, and the ability to harvest energy. A one-dimensional array of unit cells with internal resonators was designed and constructed based on the resonator lattice model. The unit cell consists of a resonator unit made of a spring-loaded magnet enclosed in a capped PMMA tube equipped with copper coils, which doubles as a linear generator. The existence of the band gap close to the LRF (140.6 Hz) as predicted by the theoretical model was verified experimentally. The device generated a peak voltage of 3.03 V, and a single cell generated an output power of 36 mW with a load of 1 Ω under harmonic excitation close to the LRF with amplitude of about 10 µm. This demonstrates the ability of such structures to power simple electronic devices harvesting energy from relatively small amplitude vibrations.

The system also offers some additional applications. The energy harvesting circuit can be used as a transducer to measure the LRF of a unit cell. A simple shaker test and tap test were used to experimentally measure the LRF of the unit cells used in the specimen. The first global natural frequency of the structure can also be estimated from the beat frequency of the voltage generated by each unit cell. This technique can be implemented in any structure with a ferromagnetic resonating component.
